In Dominique Bourn's From Groups to Categorical Algebra, there's Definition 1.4.1 (near the beginning, so visible from Amazon's preview sample) that in a category E\mathbb{E}E a reflexive graph RRR on XXX is a pair of split epis d0d_0d0​ and d1d_1d1​ with a common section s0s_0s0​:
image.png
Example 1.4.3 is X×XX\times XX×X on XXX where the split epis are the product projections p0Xp_0^Xp0X​ and p1Xp_1^Xp1X​ with common section the diagonal map s0Xs_0^Xs0X​.
A morphism of reflexive graphs is then defined to be a pair of maps forming a square, one map from domain to domain, and the other from codomain to codomain, of the reflexive graphs, 'making the diagram commute'.
(*) I am not sure whether this means that just the squares indexed by 0 and 1 ought to commute or also the square formed with the sections.
Part of Exercise 1.4.5 asks to show that there is a unique morphism from the reflexive graph in Definition 1.4.1 to the reflexive graph in Example 1.4.3.
image.png
I haven't been able to show that such a pair ((g0,g1),f)((g_0,g_1),f)((g0​,g1​),f) must be unique.
Some things I've worked out in this exercise are as follows.
Since at least the squares indexed by 0 and 1 must commute, we have f∘d0=g0f\circ d_0=g_0f∘d0​=g0​ and f∘d1=g1f\circ d_1=g_1f∘d1​=g1​. Precomposing these equations by first going along s0s_0s0​ gives f∘d0∘s0=g0∘s0f\circ d_0 \circ s_0=g_0\circ s_0f∘d0​∘s0​=g0​∘s0​ and f∘d1∘s0=g1∘s0f\circ d_1 \circ s_0=g_1\circ s_0f∘d1​∘s0​=g1​∘s0​. Using the property of split epis this reduces to g0∘s0=f=g1∘s0g_0\circ s_0=f=g_1\circ s_0g0​∘s0​=f=g1​∘s0​. Since in this case the section on the bottom of the diagram is just the diagonal map, the uncertainty I expressed in (*) does not make any difference here, as the square formed with the sections commutes anyways.
There's also that each did_idi​ is the coequalizer of (1R,s0∘di)(1_R,s_0\circ d_i)(1R​,s0​∘di​). Since gi=f∘dig_i=f\circ d_igi​=f∘di​ does coequalize (1R,s0∘di)(1_R,s_0\circ d_i)(1R​,s0​∘di​), fff is unique for each gig_igi​.
So although it looks as if given one component of the pair, the other is uniquely determined, I can't guarantee there isn't some other pair satisfying the same equations.
I'm hoping to get help solving this as the rest of the book depends on this unique morphism, which is given the name dRd_RdR​.

Thanks your suggestions were helpful. I put images now. That's great hopefully we can collaborate. I haven't been able to move past this point. The book is very cool. The interspersed exercises and cryptic nature of the following material unless you have solved them makes it similar to Paul Halmos's Linear Algebra Problem Book except for category theory.
I don’t know if I will have the time to study the book soon but I’ll try to help you on your question as soon as I can.
« making the diagram commute » means that all the paths from a same object to another same object must be equal.
so all the squares must commute in this definition

You could be right that the square with the sections must commute as well. He can't have meant that the diagram is commutative in it's entirety, though, because it would imply that d0=d1d_0=d_1d0​=d1​. Also later on in Corollary 1.6.4, although it is in a different context, he mentions diagrams indexed by 0 and 1. I am not sure whether this hints that was his intended meaning here.
I think he means that all the squares in the diagram commute (probably).
Think about how a classical graph is a graph in this sense in the category of sets and it should become clearer what must be a morphism of graphs in any category
You can also try to do these exercises in the category of sets first
Let’s say we have two reflexive graphs (in the category of sets).
What is a reflexive graph in this case?
It is given by a set GGG of edges
And a set XXX of vertices
each edge has a domain and a codomain
and each vertex has an edge from itself to itself (the identity edge of the vertex)
Say we have two reflexive graphs G1,G2G_1,G_2G1​,G2​
What is a map from G1G_1G1​ to G2G_2G2​?
You want to map each edge to an edge and each vertex to a vertex, in a coherent way
Also you want to map each identity edge to an identity edge
At the end, you want three equations to be verified: one about the domains, one about the codomains and one about the identities edges

Namely, if I send the edge eee to the edge f(e)f(e)f(e), the vertex dom(e)dom(e)dom(e) to the vertex g(dom(e))g(dom(e))g(dom(e)) and the vertex cod(e)cod(e)cod(e) to the vertex g(cod(e)g(cod(e)g(cod(e), I want:

  • dom(f(e))=g(dom(e))dom(f(e))=g(dom(e))dom(f(e))=g(dom(e))
  • cod(f(e))=g(cod(e))cod(f(e))=g(cod(e))cod(f(e))=g(cod(e))

And for the identity vertices, I want that

  • the identity s(v)s(v)s(v) of the vertex vvv is send to the identity of the vertex g(v)g(v)g(v) (here the equation involve the sections):
    s(g(v))=f(s(v))s(g(v))=f(s(v))s(g(v))=f(s(v))

I didn’t use the same notations (I just tried to explain informally) but it must be clear now what the 333 required equations in the text mean and that we want exactly these three equations to define a morphism of reflexive graphs (I hope).
Ok I understand now, thanks. So yes the square with the sections must commute.
I haven’t yet read all your questions by the way. I try to understand the text and your questions in parallel
The idea of a reflexive relation is that it is a reflexive graph but with at most on edge between any two vertices.

It is like a poset which is a category where there the arrows are just here to say that an object is smaller than another one. The arrows don’t have any content. The question is just to know whether there is one between two given objects.
The idea of the indiscrete relation on an object is that it relates any two elements of the object.
That makes sense, good point.

I think maybe a counterexample to the claimed uniqueness, using the example of the category of sets, is if in the diagram the reflexive graph RRR on XXX can be transformed by a symmetry, some permutation of the vertices that preserves the incidence with the edges, like the rigid motions in the plane in the dihedral groups. Then both this symmetry fff with its corresponding map (g0,g1)(g_0,g_1)(g0​,g1​) from RRR to X×XX\times XX×X ensuring that incidence is preserved, and the identity symmetry 1X1_X1X​ with the map (dom,cod)(dom,cod)(dom,cod) would work as morphisms into the indiscrete relation (or complete graph) on the vertices.
What is probably true is that there is a unique map from any reflexive graph on XXX to the indiscrete reflexive relation on XXX which is the identity on vertices, in any category.

The original statement is false in the category of sets for every set XXX of cardinal ≥2\ge 2≥2. You can map any reflexive graph all to the same vertex and same identity edge in the indiscrete reflexive relation. And you can do it for any choice of “receiving vertex”.
(This is a generalization to reflexive graphs of the notion of constant functor.)
Oh yeah, hadn't thought of that. Thanks for your help on this.
